Question: How can I calculate the sum of an array in Java?
Please using this api: Arrays.stream.
Answer:<<<api>>>: Arrays.stream
<<<code>>>: int[] array = {1, 2, 3, 4, 5};
int sum = Arrays.stream(array).sum();
<<<explanation>>>: The sum() method of the IntStream class returns the sum of elements in this stream. This is a special case of a reduction. This is a terminal operation.
Question: IP subnet verification in JSP: :I have the following JSP code, that protects my web page and displays it only to know IP'sString ip_h = request.getRemoteAddr();  String host_h = request.getRemoteHost();  String iplist[] = new String[1];  iplist[0] = "127.0.0.1";  iplist[1] = "10.217.106.248";  int count = iplist.length;  boolean flag = false;  int zz = 0;  //return;System.out.println(host_h);  while ( (flag==false) && ( zz < count) )  {     if (ip_h.equals(iplist[zz]) || host_h.equals(iplist[zz]) )     {        flag = true;     }     zz++;  }However, I would to rather check for subnet ranges, i.e. all users belonging to 10.217.0.0/16 are allowed.How do I do this?
Please using this api: StringTokenizer.nextToken.
Answer:

Question: IP subnet verification in JSP: :I have the following JSP code, that protects my web page and displays it only to know IP'sString ip_h = request.getRemoteAddr();  String host_h = request.getRemoteHost();  String iplist[] = new String[1];  iplist[0] = "127.0.0.1";  iplist[1] = "10.217.106.248";  int count = iplist.length;  boolean flag = false;  int zz = 0;  //return;System.out.println(host_h);  while ( (flag==false) && ( zz < count) )  {     if (ip_h.equals(iplist[zz]) || host_h.equals(iplist[zz]) )     {        flag = true;     }     zz++;  }However, I would to rather check for subnet ranges, i.e. all users belonging to 10.217.0.0/16 are allowed.How do I do this?
Please using this api: StringTokenizer.nextToken.
Answer:<<<api>>>: StringTokenizer.nextToken
<<<code>>>: StringTokenizer st = new StringTokenizer("10.217.0.0/16", ".");
String ip = st.nextToken();
String mask = st.nextToken();
<<<explanation>>>: The nextToken() method of the StringTokenizer class returns the next token from this string tokenizer. This is a special case of a split. This is a terminal operation.
